title: Dynamic Load Balancing Based on Constrained K-D Tree Decomposition for Parallel Particle Tracing
authors: Jiang Zhang, Hanqi Guo, Tom Peterka, Xiaoru Yuan
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois, United States
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois, United States
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 4 - Ins: Beijing Engineering Technology Research Center of Virtual Simulation and Visualization, Peking University
keywords: Flow Visualization; Distributed Systems and Grid Environments; Scalability Issues
abstract: Particle tracing is a fundamental technique in flow field data visualization. In this work, we present a novel dynamic load balancing method for parallel particle tracing. Specifically, we employ a constrained k-d tree decomposition approach to dynamically redistribute tasks among processes. Each process is initially assigned a regularly partitioned block along with duplicated ghost layer under the memory limit. During particle tracing, the k-d tree decomposition is dynamically performed by constraining the cutting planes in the overlap range of duplicated data. This ensures that each process is reassigned particles as even as possible, and on the other hand the new assigned particles for a process always locate in its block. Result shows good load balance and high efficiency of our method.

title: The Media Usage
authors: Zhengyan Yu
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Northeastern University, Boston, Massachusetts, United States
keywords: Data Transformation and Representation
abstract: It was my media usage throughout a week. I divided the media tools into three parts:phone, computer, and books. Also, I made several categories of different types of media usage:news, social media, learning, and software. By doing so, I can show the different and interesting dimension of the time spent on media.

title: GraphLDA: Latent Dirichlet Allocation-based Visual Exploration of Dynamic Graphs
authors: Lijing Lin, Siming Chen, Fan Hong, Chufan Lai, Shuai Chen, Xiaoru Yuan
keywords: Graph/Network Data; Visual Knowledge Discovery; Time-varying Data
abstract: In dynamic graph visualization and analysis, it is very challenging to visualize both the overall evolution of trends and the detailed changes of structures simultaneously. In this work, we propose a latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) -based visual exploration method for dynamic graphs. With the LDA-based analysis, we can reveal important structures in the dynamic graph based on the extracted se- mantic topics. To gain a deeper understanding of the derived structures and their evolution, we propose a visual analytics pipeline enabling users to interpret and explore the dynamic graph. To experiment with the proposed method, we provide a visual analytics system to test with real-world data. Our case on the datasets of dynamic collaboration network has demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Classification and Visualization for Symbolic People Flow Data Preserving Way Points and Staying Times
authors: Yuri Miyagi, Masaki Onishi, Chiemi Watanabe, Takayuki Itoh, Masahiro Takatsuka
keywords: Time-varying Data; Compression Techniques
abstract: People flow information brings us useful knowledge in various industrial and social fields including traffic, disaster prevention and marketing. However, it is still an open problem to develop effective people flow analysis techniques. We suppose compression and data mining techniques are especially important for analysis and visualization of large-scale people flow datasets. This paper presents a visualization tool for large-scale people flow dataset featuring compression and data mining techniques. This tool firstly compresses the people flow datasets using UniversalSAX, an extended method of SAX (Symbolic Aggregate Approximation). Next process is extraction and classification of movement patterns focusing on way points and staying times. Finally, the tool visualize trajectories of people flow and extracted features such as popular walking routes and congestions. We had experiments of classifying and visualizing walking routes using two types of people flow dataset recorded at an exhibition. The results allow us to discover characteristic movements such as stopping at particular places or popular walking routes.

title: Volume Rendering on Vector Machines
authors: Nobuaki Ohno, Wei Zhang
keywords: Volume Rendering; Irregular and Unstructured Grids
abstract: A particle-based volume rendering (PBVR) program was modified to accommodate vector machines towards in-situ visualization. PBVR is an effective method for the visualization of unstructured data. The algorithm was first modified to improve its performance on vector machines, after which its performance evaluation was carried out on the Earth Simulator. It is concluded that PBVR is a good candidate for in-situ visualization on vector machines.

title: Dougong Bracket Sets Shape Grammars
authors: Tai-Chen Chou, Tung-Ju Hsieh, Pei-Ying Chiang
keywords: Human-Computer Interaction
abstract: Dougong is a major structural element in traditional Chinese architecture. Dougong sets have a variety of shapes and designs depending on the importance of a building. Constructing 3D models of Dougong manually is a time-consuming and challenging task. This paper presents Dougong shape grammars for fast modeling \ of Dougong sets so that Dougong sets can be modeled either interactively \ or automatically. In this study, we develop Dougong shape grammars to describe the assembling process of Dougong sets. Dougong shape grammars are encoded using XML. AWebGL-based system is developed for parsing shape grammars for user interaction \ and fast construction.

title: Outlier Identification of Plantar Pressure Data
authors: Chen-Hsiang Liao, Tung-Ju Hsieh
keywords: Parallel Coordinates
abstract: Plantar pressure data is an important foundation for sports studies. It includes 20 parameters from the index arch, left foot, and right foot plantar pressure. It causes data observation inconvenient because of complicated property and outlier. We developed a database platform for users to import plantar pressure to the database. We used outlier identification to help sports researchers studying plantar pressure data. We used plantar pressure devisee to collect plantar pressure data sets obtained from different groups of college athletes. The data sets contain a total of 1,006 participants from 26 different sport teams. In order to research foot symptoms, we propose using visualization of plantar pressure data sets for comparative visualization using parallel coordinate. Average values and standard deviation of data sets are computed. We look for outliers in the data sets using a range of statistical values such as standard deviation. It can help sports researchers to identify outliers who have high risk of symptoms. We studied tennis, table tennis, and badminton. Sports researchers can use comparative visualization to compare difference data sets. It can save sports researchers time in operate plantar data sets and help them to make observation between different sports. Further, they can diagnose foot symptoms from the clustering in the data sets.

title: Abstractocyte: A Visual Tool for Exploring Nanoscale Astroglial Cell Morphology
authors: Haneen Mohammed, Ali Al-Awami, Johanna Beyer, Corrado Cali, Pierre Magistretti, Hanspeter Pfister, Markus Hadwiger
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
Primary Affiliation 6 - Institution: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States
Primary Affiliation 7 - Institution: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
keywords: Biomedical and Medical Visualization; Integrating Spatial and Non-Spatial Data Visualization; Visual Design
abstract: We present Abstractocyte, a novel visualization system for the detailed analysis of astrocytes in brain tissue. Astrocytes are nonneuronal cells in the brain, which are support structures for neurons. In order to image astrocytes and their fine sub-structures, high resolution imaging is required. However, the complex and widely branching morphology of astrocytes makes visualization and analysis challenging. Most previous visualization research has focused on the analysis of neurons and synapses, while ignoring the analysis of astrocytes. In Abstractocyte, biologists can simultaneously explore the morphology of astrocyte cells while analysing neighboring neurons and their neural connectivity. We allow users to explore their data at different levels of abstraction. Users can go from a concrete, highly-detailed 3D view to a simplified and abstracted 2D view of the same data. This abstraction can be done independently for astrocytes as well as for neurites, thereby spanning a 2D space of possible abstraction levels. Our system morphs from one abstraction level to the next, either by smoothly interpolating, or by snapping from one abstraction level to the next. Such approach is of particular interest to assess astrocytic coverage of synapses, a feature of great interest to neuroscientists as the morphological relationship between astrocytes and neurons impacts energy support, recycling of transmitters, and fine-tuning of synaptic activity. Abstractocyte was designed to support the analysis tasks our collaborators have identified as critical to their research. Here we report initial feedback from them.

title: Multilevel Visual Analysis of Multivariate Radio Signal Data
authors: chufan lai, Lu Feng, Xiaoru Yuan
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Key Laboratory of Machine Perception (Ministry of Education), and School of EECS, Peking University, Beijing, Beijing, China
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Key Laboratory of Machine Perception (Ministry of Education), and School of EECS, Peking University, Beijing, Beijing, China
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Key Laboratory of Machine Perception (Ministry of Education) and School of EECS, Peking University, Beijing, China
keywords: Intelligence Analysis; Data Filtering; Time Series Data; Dimensionality Reduction; Coordinated and Multiple Views; Multidimensional Data; Multiresolution Techniques
abstract: Radio signal is an essential part in wireless communication, which can shed lights on various communication patterns. In previous works, its temporal and frequency-domain features have been thoroughly studied. But the multivariate features were not fully explored. In this work, we develop a visual analytic system to facilitate multilevel and multivariate analysis towards large scale radio signal data. Our system tightly integrates data analysis in time, frequency and multivariate domains. Specifically, it promotes attribute-based analysis and subspace feature mining using multivariate visualization techniques. It also promotes large scale signal data analysis by multilevel visual designs and database techniques. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our system by a use case with real-world signal data.

title: Decoupling Ensemble Data Using Subspaces
authors: Fan Hong, Xiaoru Yuan, Alex Pang, Chufan Lai, Brad Hollister, Xiaoguang Ma, Pierre Lermusiaux
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: University of California, Santa Cruz, California, United States
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
Primary Affiliation 6 - Institution: State Key Laboratory of Numerical Modeling for Atmospheric Sciences and Geophysical Fluid Dynamics, Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Primary Affiliation 7 - Institution: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States
keywords: Scalar Field Data; Data Clustering; Multi-field, Multi-modal and Multi-variate Data; Uncertainty Visualization
abstract: Locations and simulations runs are two important aspects of ensemble data. Existing methods either compare regional or locational features extracted from runs, or compare simulation runs over the spatial domain. By decoupling only one aspect and aggregating the other, the coordinated behaviors between run subsets and location subsets are concealed. In this work, we introduce the concept of ensemble subspace inspired by high-dimensional data visualization, and suggest a more informative approach to explore ensemble data, that is to simultaneously decouple the locations and runs. Biclustering-based method is employed for ensemble subspace extraction, thus enables the exploration of coordinated behaviors in ensemble data. We build a system to support extraction and exploration of coordinated behaviors in ensemble subspaces. Our case studies have shown plenty of results about coordinated behaviors, which are difficult to find with existing tools.

title: SignalTreeExplorer: A Multi-Tree Comparison System for Visually Exploring Time Sequential Communication Data
authors: Guozheng Li, Yu Zhang, Siming Chen, Haocheng Zhang, Jie Liang, Xiaoju Dong, jinsong wang, Xiaoru Yuan
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: University of Technology, Sydney, Sydney, Australia
Primary Affiliation 6 - Institution: Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
keywords: Hierarchy Data; Visual Analysis Models; Time Series Data
abstract: With the rapid development of communication technology, the capability of providing situation awareness in the scenarios with complex communication data is essential. Communication data have hierarchical structure and could be built as signal trees. However, the quick generation, considerable diversity, and complex patterns/anomalies of signal trees presents a great challenge for understanding and exploring communication data for analysts. We propose SignalTreeExplorer to facilitate visual analysis for time sequential communication data, through comparison of multiple signal trees at different granularity level concurrently. Furthermore, usage scenarios in this paper which help analysts gain insights into patterns and anomalies of communication data demonstrate the usefulness of SignalTreeExplorer.

title: ViStream : Distributed Streaming Framework using Vivaldi
authors: Woohyuk Choi, Jungmin Moon, Won-Ki Jeong
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology, Ulsan, Korea, Republic of
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology, Ulsan, Korea, Republic of
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology, Ulsan, Korea, Republic of
keywords: Distributed Systems and Grid Environments; Volume Rendering; Visualization System and Toolkit Design; Biomedical and Medical Visualization
abstract: Advances in data acquisition techniques have resulted in a volume of data that is considerably larger than that accumulated in the past. The influx of data has given rise to a new trend of processing big data through the use of streaming framework. In this paper, we pro- pose a system called ViStream, which executes applications on out-of-core data in Vivaldi. Vivaldi is a domain specific language for heterogeneous distributed systems. We improved the language to enable the rendering of primitives through the use of OpenGL and tested applications that can be processed on out-of-core data. Specifically, three applications were validated. First, we executed an application that uses streaming, that is, histogram matching for 1.3 TB of zebrafish data. Second, we ran combined visualization with volume and primitive rendering. Finally, we executed an application that shows only projected volumetric data on a 3D skeletal representation of zebrafish. \

title: Multidirectional Flow Visualization Methodology
authors: Seongmin Jeong, Seokyeon Kim, Yun Jang
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Sejong University, Seoul, Korea, Republic of
keywords: Vector Field Data; Multi-field, Multi-modal and Multi-variate Data; Geographic/Geospatial Visualization
abstract: Finding major flows and trends is an important factor in analyzing movement data. However, it is difficult to define the trend flow and the major flow when the movement data has multiple directions rather than one direction. In this paper, we explore how to effectively visualize trend flows and major flows in multi-directional data fields to illustrate multi-directional movement data. We visualize the multi- directional New York taxi data in four different styles, explaining the advantages and disadvantages of each visualization technique.

title: Visualization of the Forever 27 Club
authors: Suchismita Naik
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: National Institute of Design, Bangalore, Karnataka, India
keywords: Visualization for the Masses; Visualization Models; Visual Analysis Models; Visual Knowledge Representation; Data Clustering; Data Filtering; Time Series Data; Interaction Design; Cognition Theory; Perceptual Cognition; Time-varying Data; Multidimensional Data; Animation; Illustrative Visualization; Visual Design; Flow Visualization; Multimedia (Image/Video/Music) Visualization
abstract: This visualization is the timeline of the popular musicians who died at the age 27, often as a result of drug and alcohol abuse, violent means such as suicide or homicide. The timeline is distributed according to the cause of death and year of death. The main goal of this visualization is to make users find their own stories through data and also to create awareness among a large user base. The inspiration of this visualization is a gramophone where the details are displayed according to the position of the pointer. The choice of this style of graphical elements is made to build more empathy towards the fans of these artists in order to glorify the short-lived lives of these great artists. Interfaces are designed so as to make the visualization more interactive by providing the filters such as genres and artist types, single-frame interactivity to maintain a consistent narration flow and having detail-on-demands feature in order to reduce the cognitive load of the users.

title: TimeTubes: Visual Fusion for Ameliorating Uncertainty of Blazar Datasets from Different Observatories
authors: Naoko Sawada, Masanori Nakayama, Hsing-Yun Wu, Makoto Uemura, Issei Fujishiro
keywords: Data Fusion and Integration; Time-varying Data; Multi-field, Multi-modal and Multi-variate Data; Uncertainty Visualization
abstract: Blazars are active galactic nuclei whose relativistic jets ejected from the central black hole are pointing toward the Earth. Astronomers have attempted to classify blazars, whereas it is difficult to analyze the time-dependent multivariate datasets with the conventional visualization methods, such as animeted scatterplot matrices. In our previous study, a new visualization scheme, called TimeTubes, was proposed, which allows the astronomers to analyze dynamic changes in and feature causality among the multiple time-varying variables. In this poster, we present a core idea to ameliorate data-inherent and mapping-inherent uncertainty through visual fusion of datasets for the same blazar from two different observatories.

title: Visualization of hierarchical inter-firm transaction network with time serise
authors: Kohei Arimoto, Hidenori Watanave
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hino City, Tokyo, Japan
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hino City, Tokyo, Japan
keywords: Design Methodologies; Graph/Network Data; Hierarchy Data; Geometry-based Techniques
abstract: The aim of this research is to provide a method that would capture new transaction occurrence and fluctuations of transactions on time series intuitively. We have drawn the the start and end point of the altered link of major companies on a virtual globe. Also, using time slider enabled us to construct a visualize system whose transaction clusters changed chronologically, where the edges are colored in blue when number of transactions increases, in red when it decreases, in green when there is a new transaction. This method shows that the number of new transaction, the green color, has increased every year by the similar range. I also shows both the first and the second transactions increased in areas where new factories were built. As a result, this method enables hierarchical transaction clusters課ｪ fluctuations of transactions and new transaction occurrence to be understood intuitively.

title: Development of a Visual Analytics System for Structural Equation Modeling
authors: Yoshihiro Ashida, Kozen Umezawa, Yosuke Onoue, Koji Koyamada
keywords: Hypothesis Testing, Visual Evidence; Tabular Data
abstract: In this study, we introduce a visual analytics system for structural equation modeling (SEM) that allows analysts to efficiently build and validate statistical models.  Discovery of causality is one of the essential objectives of science. SEM is a statistical analysis method that can validate causal relationship model composed of observed and latent variables.  SEM is widely used to validate causal relationship in complex phenomena and several support tools have been developed. However, existing support tools lack functionalities for integrated visualization of model information. Our proposed system simultaneously visualizes model information using 3 types of views: graph view, matrix view, and fitness measurement table view. We demonstrate an application example using real world data to validate the concept of our proposed system.

title: Layer Hierachization in Multiplex Networks for Word Cloud Visualization
authors: Benjamin Renoust, Haolin Ren, Guy Melancon, Marie-luce Viaud
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 1 - Ins: Japanese French Laboratory of Informatics, CNRS UMI 3527, Tokyp, Japan
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 2 - Ins: CNRS UMR 5800 LaBRI University of Bordeaux
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: CNRS UMR 5800 LaBRI University of Bordeaux
keywords: Graph/Network Data; Data Clustering; Text and Document Data
abstract: Multiplex networks are heterogeneous and complex data structures: they present interacting entities across multiple layers of interactions. One successful strategy to visualize these complex structures is to exploit an additional network: This layer interaction network describes how layers overlap and may be used to investigate the original network. When the layers correspond to semantic units in documents, the new network shows some sense of semantic hierarchy reflecting the semantic context formed by the documents. We first propose an algorithm to extract hierarchical clusters of layers in a multiplex network of documents, and then to embed this hierarchy in an interactive word cloud.

title: Node-link Graphs of Human Brain Network based on Dynamical Causal Modeling for Magnetoencephalography
authors: Hiroaki NATSUKAWA, Koji KOYAMADA
keywords: Biomedical and Medical Visualization; Visual Knowledge Discovery; Graph/Network Data
abstract: Magnetoencephalography (MEG) is a non-invasive neuroimaging technique that offers high temporal resolution, which enables the analysis of the connectivity between brain regions. Dynamical causal modeling (DCM) for MEG is one of the methods for describing directed connectivity based on the neural mass model. Although DCM analyzes the human cortical directed connectivity, this interface provides only an adjacency matrix as a visual representation. Therefore, it is difficult to intuitively grasp the connectivity parameters and compare them. In this study, we proposed the visual representations (weighted node-link graph layouts: anatomical and forced-directed) of the directed connectivity of human cortical areas to visualize the results of connectivity analysis performed with DCM. Based on these visual representations, we developed a visual analytic method that enables us to compare the juxtaposed results of connectivity analyses. A user review was conducted to evaluate our proposed solution. Our proposed graph representations of DCM network were received well by two domain experts. We plan to conduct the controlled experiment to evaluate our proposed visual representation and analytics method in the near future.

title: Insight Provenance In Learning
authors: Kuatbek Mukabak, Meirambek Omyrzak, Sungahn Ko
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology, Ulsan, Ulsan, Korea, Republic of
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology, Ulsan, Ulsan, Korea, Republic of
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology, Ulsan, Ulsan, Korea, Republic of
keywords: Knowledge Externalization; Visual Knowledge Discovery; Visualization in Education
abstract: The process of sensemaking for generating insights has been researched in many directions. Insight provenance is a type of research for finding the origin of the insights. Although much research has been performed on the insight provenance with different tasks (e.g., buying a camera), rare research has been performed with open tasks that could lead more diverse directions during exploration compared to conventional tasks. Here we report our approaches for system logging and visualization as a first step for our insight provenance research.
